items.descriptor: No grammar descriptor available.
Can make simple statements with 'it's/it is'.

relatedDescriptors.descriptor: Can write times using both digits and words.
Can tell the time of day to within five minutes.
Can tell the time of day to the quarter hour.
Can give basic information about the price of something.
Can tell the time of day in full hours.
Can indicate time by such phrases as 'next week', 'last Friday', 'in November', 'three o’clock'.

additionalInformation.Variant terms: anticipatory it | anticipatory it + adjective | anticipatory it + time | anticipatory it plus adjective | anticipatory it plus time | basic it's | copula | it as subject | it pronoun | personal pronouns | pronoun it | subject verb complement | verb be | word order
additionalInformation.Example: It’s cold.; It’s ten o’clock.; It’s Monday today.; It’s easy.; It’s late.

items.descriptor: Can use subject personal pronouns.

relatedDescriptors.descriptor: Can complete a simple form asking for medical information.
Can describe what someone is wearing using a limited range of expressions.
Can describe a person's hobbies and activities using simple language.
Can exchange personal details (e.g. where they live, things they have).
Can say other people's nationalities.
Can ask and answer simple questions about people they know in a limited way.
Can say what they do (e.g. name of their job, student).
Can ask and answer basic questions about family and friends in a limited way.

additionalInformation.Variant terms: I | he | it | nominative case | personal pronouns | pronoun subjects | she | subject personal pronouns | subject pronouns | subjective case pronouns | they | we | you
additionalInformation.Example: I; you; he; she; it; we; they

items.descriptor: Can ask basic questions using 'What's your ...?'

relatedDescriptors.descriptor: Can carry out a simple informal interview.
Can write a formal email/letter requesting information.
Can invite others to give their views on what to do next.
Can ask for simple directions from X to Y on foot or by public transport.
Can ask someone for their name.
Can ask and answer questions about what they do at work and in their free time.
Can ask someone what their nationality is.
Can write a basic formal email/letter requesting information.
Can ask and answer simple questions in areas of immediate need or on very familiar topics.
Can ask someone what their job is.
Can communicate in routine tasks requiring simple, direct exchanges of information.
Can use brief, everyday expressions to ask for and give personal details.

additionalInformation.Variant terms: asking what is | basic questions with what | basic questions with what's | questions with be | wh-questions | what questions | what's questions | what's your questions
additionalInformation.Example: What's your name?; What's your job?

items.descriptor: Can use regular nouns in the plural form.

relatedDescriptors.descriptor: Can say a range of basic numbers, quantities and prices.

additionalInformation.Variant terms: noun + es | noun + s | nouns in plural | nouns in the plural | plural forms | plural nouns | plural with s | plurals with s | regular plurals
additionalInformation.Example: boys; classes; books; pens; days; chairs

items.descriptor: Can make basic statements with subject + verb + object.

relatedDescriptors.descriptor: Can use a limited range of fixed expressions to describe objects, possessions, or products.
Can write a short, simple description of a familiar device or product.

additionalInformation.Variant terms: SVO | basic word order | direct object transitive verbs | object | subject | subject + verb + direct object | subject + verb + object | verb
additionalInformation.Example: I like rock music.; She drinks coffee.; We study English.

items.descriptor: Can use subject pronouns with the correct form of the verb 'be' in the simple present.

relatedDescriptors.descriptor: Can make an introduction and use basic greeting and leave-taking expressions.
Can describe a person's hobbies and activities using simple language.
Can say other people's nationalities.
Can say what they do (e.g. name of their job, student).
Can ask and answer basic questions about family and friends in a limited way.
Can introduce themselves in a basic way, giving some information about where they live, their family etc.
Can complete a simple form asking for medical information.
Can ask and answer simple questions about people they know in a limited way.

additionalInformation.Notes: When rated, delete GLGR0029 (this replaces it)
additionalInformation.Variant terms: I | be + adjectives | be with adjectives | he | it | nominative case | personal pronouns | personal pronouns plus be | personal pronouns with be | pronoun subjects | she | subject personal pronouns | subject pronouns plus be | subject pronouns with be | subjective case pronouns | they | we | you
additionalInformation.Example: I'm French.; They're old.; She's nice.

items.descriptor: Can use the correct form of 'be' with singular and plural nouns.

relatedDescriptors.descriptor: Can say a range of basic numbers, quantities and prices.
Can describe where they live.

additionalInformation.Variant terms: agreement | agreement with to be | am | are | be | be + nouns | copula | is | nouns + be | subject verb agreement | to be
additionalInformation.Example: The coffee is hot.; The boys are Spanish.; I'm Chinese.; We're students.

items.descriptor: Can say their own age using 'I'm [number]'.

relatedDescriptors.descriptor: Can say their own age and ask someone about their age.
Can communicate in routine tasks requiring simple, direct exchanges of information.

additionalInformation.Variant terms: I am + age | I am plus age | I am plus number | say how old you are | say your age | saying how old you are | saying your age

items.descriptor: Can use 'and' to link nouns and noun phrases.

relatedDescriptors.descriptor: Can use very basic connectors like 'and', 'but', 'so' and 'then'.

additionalInformation.Variant terms: additive conjunctions | and as conjunction | and with noun phrases | and with nouns | conjunctions | coordinating conjunctions | copulative conjunctions | noun and noun | noun phrase and noun phrase
additionalInformation.Example: boys and girls; a cat and a dog; the tall man and the short woman

items.descriptor: Can recognise the letters of the alphabet.

additionalInformation.Notes: 4/30/15 MG (IRT analysis) - wording update  Apriil 2015 IRT Analysis Changes. Previous Score/CEFR were 22 - A1 -  Previous status was Published  -  Reasons for other changes -  updated wording

items.di: Use simple words and phrases in basic, brief social and interpersonal exchanges. (10-21)

items.descriptor: Can list (in Language B) names, numbers, prices and very simple information from texts (in Language A) that are of immediate interest, that are composed in very simple language and contain illustrations.

sdf.development_indicator: Extract basic key information from short texts or sources and synthesize it in a list or series of sentences. (10-30)

items.di: Extract basic key information from short texts or sources and synthesize it in a list or series of sentences. (10-30)

items.definition: to not express an opinion, or to try not to form an opinion, at least for a period of time
items.example: The chairperson should allow for plenty of discussion of the ideas, but avoid judgment him or herself. | Acknowledge how someone is feeling, but avoid judgment.

items.definition: an area of a state or country that has its own local government
items.example: Orange Country, near Los Angeles, tends to be more conservative than its neighbor. | Large parts of the county flooded in the recent storms.

items.definition: used when telling someone what you think they should do
items.example: If I were you, I'd deal with this first.

topics.description: Engaging in group dialogue around differing ideas/opinions
Managing work responsibilities within a group

items.definition: the process of doing something, or something that someone does
items.example: They called for urgent action to reduce unemployment. | Her actions probably saved my life.

topics.description: Managing setbacks and challenges in group work
Managing work responsibilities within a group

items.definition: the activity of planning and arranging something so that it is successful or effective
items.example: Putting on a show of this kind involves considerable organisation.

items.definition: to use something as an example, in order to make something easier to understand, or prove that it is true
items.example: I want to give you an illustration of how the media can influence people's opinions.

topics.description: Managing setbacks and challenges in group work

items.definition: use this to ask someone's opinion about a situation or idea
items.example: What's your take on the political situation? | Maria, you've worked on similar projects before, what's your take on the problem?

topics.description: Engaging in group dialogue around differing ideas/opinions

items.definition: used when telling someone that they should try to do something, when giving instructions
items.example: Try to keep your back straight and your legs bent.

topics.description: Engaging in group dialogue around differing ideas/opinions
Managing work responsibilities within a group

items.definition: used to ask for information about something
items.example: What does your audience know already? What attitudes or biases do they have?

items.definition: feeling or expressing fear or hatred of people from other races
